DOC.HEAD: Advisory Committee Finds Radiation Safety Procedures Lacking
DOC.TEXT: A Texas nuclear weapons assembly plant where radioactive gas was accidentally released last spring was unprepared for such an emergency, an Energy Department advisory committee says. ``It is still unclear that effective control of the situation by an adequately prepared response team ever took place,'' John F. Ahearne, chairman of the Advisory Committee on Nuclear Facility Safety, said in a letter about the Pantex plant in Amarillo, Texas. The letter to Energy Secretary James D. Watkins, released Monday, also raised questions about safety and environmental practices at Pantex, the nation's only final assembly plant for nuclear bombs and missile warheads. The committee said the response to the May release of tritium, a radioactive gas, was of ``variable quality.'' Radiation specialists and technicians responded properly to minimize workers' exposure at the plant, the report said. ``Missing was recognition that this `unlikely event' could take place, and thus adequate procedures, instrumentation and training were lacking,'' the letter said. Although a quick and effective evacuation was conducted, thereafter, ``events are marked by confusion, misread instruments and uncertain actions. There appeared to be no plan to handle what surely must be an anticipated accident,'' the report said. Pantex spokesman Tom Walton said the plant has begun correcting problems or ``will be addressing those in the very near future.'' Some safety violations were corrected on the spot. The report said cleaning up the facility after the accident was estimated to cost $1 million ``and the psychological trauma on the individuals exposed.'' Exposure to workers, however, was below federal guidelines limiting radiation exposure and ``off-site exposure was trivial.'' The letter said the committee found a ``lack of belief that Pantex can have radiological accidents, in spite of the recent tritium accident.'' A ``tiger team'' of government and outside experts also recently inspected the plant and found Pantex would be unable to respond effectively to emergencies involving releases of radioactive material. Watkins said those findings indicate workers lack adequate protection from emergency and routine exposure to radioactive releases and that the situation must be corrected immediately. The advisory committee, which spent two days in Amarillo last month, found ``an apparent lack of sophistication and depth regarding environmental problems'' at Pantex. Monitoring of possible ground water contamination with wells at Pantex also has been less than systematic, the letter said. ``This issue has just not received a great deal of attention. This is particularly unfortunate since ground water contamination, if found, would be a threat to the sole source of drinking water for the area,'' the letter said.
